revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2011}} {{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}} {{Infobox musical artist | name =Kenny G | image = Kenny-G.jpg | caption = Kenny G playing in Shanghai | image_size = 250px | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = Kenneth Bruce Gorelick | alias = Kenny G | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1956|6|5}} | death_date = | origin = [[Seattle, Washington]], US | instrument = '''Primary:'''
[[Soprano saxophone]]
'''Secondary:'''
[[Alto saxophone]]
[[Tenor saxophone]]
[[Flute]] | genre = [[Smooth jazz]]
[[Adult contemporary]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter, record producer | years_active = 1973–1982 (group)
1982–present (solo) | label = [[Arista Records|Arista]] (1982–2006)
[[Concord Records|Concord]] (2008–present) | associated_acts = Robin Thicke, [[Foster the People]] | website = [http://www.kennyg.com/ www.kennyg.com] | notable_instruments = }}'''Kenneth Bruce Gorelick''' (born June 5, 1956), better known by his stage name '''Kenny G''', is an American [[adult contemporary]] and [[smooth jazz]] [[saxophonist]]. His fourth album, ''[[Duotones]]'', brought him breakthrough success in 1986.{{cite web |url= http://music.barnesandnoble.com/features/interview.asp?NID=598266&z=y|title= Kenny G Is Still the Smooth Jazz King|accessdate=April 7, 2007 |month= October | year= 2002|publisher=Barnes & Noble.com}} Kenny G is the biggest-selling instrumental musician of the modern era, with global sales totaling more than 75 million albums.{{cite news | first=Preston | last=Turegano | title=Kenny G – Grammy winner and best-selling instrumental musician of the modern era | date=2009-09 | publisher=Smooth Jazz News | url =http://smoothjazznews.com/archives/september2009/index.html | work=Smooth Jazz News | accessdate =April 5, 2010 }} == Early life == Kenny G was born in [[Seattle]], [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] to Jewish parents (his mother was originally from [[Saskatchewan]], [[Canada]]) and grew up in the city's [[Seward Park, Seattle|Seward Park]] neighborhood, which is a center of the city's Jewish community. He came into contact with a saxophone when he heard someone performing with one on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]''. He started playing the saxophone in 1966 when he was 10 years old. He learned how to play under the direction of local trumpeter [[Gerald Pfister]] and by practicing along with [[Gramophone record|record]]s (mostly of [[Grover Washington, Jr.]]), trying to emulate the sounds that he was hearing. His first saxophone was a [[Buffet Crampon]] alto.{{cite web|url=http://kennyg.com/blog/ |title=Some more Q & A |accessdate=April 1, 2010 |author=Kenny G |date=June 19, 2009 |work=Kenny G Rhythm and Romance }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Kenny G attended Whitworth Elementary School, [[Sharples Junior High School]], [[Franklin High School (Seattle, Washington)|Franklin High School]], and the [[University of Washington]], all in his home town of Seattle. When he entered high school, he failed on his first try to get into the jazz band, but tried again the following year and earned first chair.{{cite web |url= http://www.golfdigest.com/golf-tours-news/2006-12/kennyg|title= After selling millions of records, Grammy winner Kenny G wants to conquer golf|accessdate=April 7, 2007 |last= Diaz|first= Jaime|month= December |year= 2006|publisher=GolfDigest.com}}{{cite news |first= Ron|last= Kroichick|title= Kenny G can swing with the best of them|url=http://www.scrippsnews.com/node/19279 |work=Scripps News|publisher=ScrippsNews.com|date= February 7, 2007|accessdate=April 7, 2007 }} In addition to his studies while in high school, he took private lessons on the saxophone and clarinet from Johnny Jessen, once a week for a year.{{cite journal|title=I'm just doing my own thing, too|journal=Jazzed|year=2006|first=Christian|last=Wissmuller|issue=December/January|id= |url=http://www.jazzedmagazine.com/ME2/dirmod.asp?sid=DB82F62537074828BBCEEDE627080729&nm=Archives&type=Publishing&mod=Publications%3A%3AArticle&mid=8F3A7027421841978F18BE895F87F791&tier=4&id=DC361A86F0E94F41ACBF6EC31A485461|accessdate=April 1, 2010 }} He was also on his high school golf team. He had loved the sport ever since his older [[sibling|brother]], Brian Gorelick, introduced it to him when he was ten years old, which is the same age he was when he started playing the saxophone. == Career == Kenny G's career started with a job as a sideman for [[Barry White]]'s [[Love Unlimited Orchestra]] in 1973 while 17 and still in high school.{{cite encyclopedia |last=Glenn |first=Alan |editor= |encyclopedia=Encyclopedia.com |title=Kenny G |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Kenny_G.aspx |accessdate=April 1, 2010 |edition= |year=1995 |publisher=HighBeam Research, Inc |id= |quote= }}{{cite web |url= {{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p5924/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title= Kenny G Biography|accessdate=April 7, 2007 |last= Yanow|first= Scott|publisher=AllMusic.com}} He continued to play professionally while studying for a [[academic major|major]] in accounting at the [[University of Washington]] in Seattle and graduated [[magna cum laude]].{{cite web |url= http://www.bmi.com/musicworld/entry/233313|title= Kenny G Has Time on his Side|accessdate=April 7, 2007 |last= Zimmerman|first= Kevin|date= September 30, 2002|publisher=BMI.com}} He played with the [[funk]] band Cold, Bold & Together before becoming a credited member of The [[Jeff Lorber]] Fusion. He began his solo career after his period with Lorber. Kenny G signed with [[Arista Records]] as a solo artist in 1982, after [[record label|label]] president [[Clive Davis]] heard his rendition of ABBA's "Dancing Queen". He has released many [[solo album]]s and collaborated with various artists including [[Andrea Bocelli]], [[Whitney Houston]],{{cite encyclopedia | last = Sandow| first = Greg| authorlink= Greg Sandow| year = 2007| title = Kenny G| url= http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761584562/Kenny_G.html| accessdate =May 4, 2007| encyclopedia = Microsoft Encarta| publisher=[[Microsoft Corporation]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5kwsEhS4b|archivedate=October 31, 2009|deadurl=yes}} [[Peabo Bryson]], [[Aaron Neville]], [[Toni Braxton]], [[DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince]],{{cite web |url= {{Allmusic|class=album|id=r240956/credits|pure_url=yes}}|title= The Moment – Credits|accessdate=May 7, 2007 |publisher=Allmusic}} [[Natalie Cole]],{{cite web |url= {{Allmusic|class=album|id=r4311/credits|pure_url=yes}}|title= Everlasting – Credits|accessdate=May 7, 2007 |publisher=Allmusic}} [[Steve Miller (musician)|Steve Miller]]{{cite web |url= {{Allmusic|class=album|id=r13073/credits|pure_url=yes}}|title= Living in the 20th Century – Credits|accessdate=May 7, 2007 |publisher=Allmusic}} (which marked the only time he appeared on a [[rock and roll]] album), [[Dudley Moore]], [[Lee Ritenour]], [[The Rippingtons]], [[Michael Bolton]], [[Celine Dion]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Smokey Robinson]], [[Bebel Gilberto]], [[George Benson]], [[Chante Moore]] and [[Aretha Franklin]]. Influenced by the likes of saxophonist [[Grover Washington, Jr.]], his own albums are usually classified as [[smooth jazz]]. He received success quite early on, with both ''[[G Force]]'' and ''[[Gravity (Kenny G album)|Gravity]]'', his second and third studio albums respectively, achieving [[music recording sales certification|platinum status]] in the United States. These sales were topped by his fourth studio album, ''[[Duotones]]'', which sold over 5 million copies in the U.S. alone. His sixth studio album, ''[[Breathless (Kenny G album)|Breathless]]'', became the number one best selling instrumental album ever, with over 15 million copies sold, of which 12 million were in the U.S. He broke another record when his first holiday album, ''[[Miracles: The Holiday Album|Miracles]]'', sold over 13 million copies, making it the most successful Christmas album to date. In 1997, Kenny G earned a place in the ''[[Guinness Book of World Records]]'' for playing the longest note ever recorded on a saxophone. Using [[circular breathing]], Kenny G held an E-flat for 45 minutes and 47 seconds at J&R Music World in New York City.{{cite news |title=Kenny G. Blows |url=http://music.yahoo.com/kenny-g/news/kenny-g-blows--12037787 |publisher=Yahoo! |id= |date=December 2, 1997 |accessdate=2012-01-08 |quote= }} That same year, Kenny G's song "[[Havana (song)|Havana]]", from his album ''[[The Moment (Kenny G album)|The Moment]]'', was remixed by noted DJs [[Todd Terry]] and [[Tony Moran]] and released promotionally to dance clubs in the U.S. These mixes went to No.1 on the ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Dance Club Play|Dance/Club Play Songs]] chart in April 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/dance-club-play-songs?chartDate=1997-04-26#/charts/dance-club-play-songs?chartDate=1997-04-26 |title=Dance/Club Play Songs – Week of April 26, 1997|accessdate=April 9, 2010 |work=Billboard }} Kenny G's 1999 single, "[[What A Wonderful World]]" was criticized in its overdubbing of [[Louis Armstrong]]'s classic recording. The primary criticism is that a revered recording by an artist such as Armstrong, known especially for improvisation, should not be altered, especially by a musician whose range and depth of understanding of classical jazz was already in question.Ben Ratliff [http://www.nytimes.com/2000/07/16/arts/music-jazz-can-take-itself-too-seriously.html MUSIC; Jazz Can Take Itself Too Seriously] ''[[New York Times]]'', July 16, 2000Mark Sabbatini [http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/article.php?id=15999 Kenny G: At Last...The Duets Album] ''[[All About Jazz]]'', December 30, 2004George Varga [http://jazztimes.com/articles/20699-kenny-g-changes-his-tune Kenny G: Changes His Tune] ''[[JazzTimes]]'' May 1999Mike Joyce [http://jazztimes.com/articles/24803-who-s-overrated-who-s-underrated Who's overrated? Who's Underrated?] ''[[JazzTimes]]'', September 1997 Some columnists counter the criticism by suggesting that Kenny G's recording would expose a wider audience to classic jazz, though the overall response to his recording tended to be extremely negative.{{cite news | first=Shirley | last=Maldonado | title=Gee whiz, give Kenny a break | date=August 10, 2000 | publisher=Boston Herald and Herald Media | url =http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/57812085.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Aug+10%2C+2000&author=Shirley+Maldonado&pub=Boston+Herald&edition=&startpage=049&desc=Gee+whiz%2C+give+Kenny+a+break | work=Boston Herald | accessdate =April 7, 2010 }} Kenny G has recorded some Chinese songs, such as "[[Mo Li Hua|Jasmine Flower]]" (茉莉花) or "[[The Moon Represents My Heart]]" (月亮代表我的心). His music is noticeably popular in China. His recording "Going Home" is often played at closing time at public places or at the end of classes at schools. Mass transit systems in [[Tianjin]] and Shanghai play these songs when trains approach terminus stations. As of 2003, Kenny G was named the 25th-highest selling artist in America by the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]], with 48 million albums sold in the USA as of July 31, 2006.{{cite web |url= http://www.riaa.com/gp/bestsellers/topartists.asp|title= Top Artists|accessdate=April 7, 2007 |date= July 31, 2006|publisher=RIAA.com |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070304033156/http://www.riaa.com/gp/bestsellers/topartists.asp |archivedate = March 4, 2007}} In 1994, Kenny G won the [[Grammy Award for Best Instrumental Composition]] for ''Forever in Love''. In October 2009, Kenny G appeared with the band [[Weezer]] in an [[AOL]] promotion of their album ''[[Raditude]]'' by soloing during "I'm Your Daddy". Kenny G said he knew nothing of Weezer before the performance.Charley Rogulewski [http://www.spinner.com/2009/10/23/weezer-run-with-chamillionaire-sara-bareilles-and-kenny-g/ Weezer Run With Chamillionaire, Sara Bareilles and ... Kenny G?] ''[[Spinner.com]]'', Oct 23, 2009 Though some music critics thereby rejoined in the common criticism of his work,Tom Breihan [http://pitchfork.com/news/36899-weezer-team-up-with-kenny-g-chamillionaire-sara-bareilles/ Weezer Team Up With Kenny G, Chamillionaire, Sara Bareilles] ''[[Pitchfork Media]]'', October 23, 2009Mike Burr [http://www.prefixmag.com/news/weezer-breaks-out-rolodex-brings-kenny-g-chamillio/34005/ Weezer Breaks Out Rolodex, Brings Kenny G., Chamillionaire, and Sara Bareilles To AOL Session] ''Prefix Magazine'' , October 23, 2009 the unlikely combination was fairly well received by AOL's magazines ''[[Spinner.com]]'' and ''Popeater.com''.[http://www.popeater.com/2009/10/26/kenny-g-steps-back-into-the-spotlight/ Kenny G Steps Back Into the Spotlight] ''popeater.com'', October 26, 2009 In February 2011 Kenny G and his music were featured in a [[Super Bowl XLV]] ad for Audi called "Release the Hounds."[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3snyXTNmFm8 Audi Big Game Commercial 2011 – Release the Hounds] ''youtube.com'', February 2, 2011 Kenny G later starred in a short film detailing his time as Head of Riot Suppression for the Luxury Prison.[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oXE6L2gUDKQ Audi Big Game 2011 Teaser – Kenny G Riot Suppressor (Part 2)] ''youtube.com'', February 1, 2011 Recently, he made an appearance in the music video for pop star Katy Perry's single [[Last Friday Night (T.G.I.F.)]] as Uncle Kenny. On the October 8, 2011 episode of [[Saturday Night Live (season 37)|Saturday Night Live]], Kenny appeared with his soprano sax along side [[alternative rock]] band [[Foster the People]] as they performed their song "Houdini." == Equipment == Kenny G plays the Selmer Mark VI Soprano, Alto and Tenor Saxophones. He has created his own line of saxophones called "Kenny G Saxophones".{{Cite web |url=http://www.kennygsaxophones.com/kennyg/Home.html |title=Kenny G Saxophones |accessdate=8 September 2012}} == Personal life == Kenny G married Lyndie Benson-Gorelick in 1992, and the couple had two sons. In January 2012, Benson-Gorelick filed for legal separation.{{cite news|last=Everett|first=Christina|title=Kenny G’s wife files for legal separation|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-01-20/news/30649204_1_wife-files-files-for-legal-separation-gabriel-aubry|accessdate=February 22, 2011|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)]]|date=January 20, 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/65eWibuPI|archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no}} Kenny G filed for divorce in August 2012.{{cite news|last=Fleeman|first=Mike|title=Kenny G Files for Divorce After 20 Years of Marriage|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20620884,00.html|accessdate=August 14, 2012|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=August 13, 2012}} Kenny G lives in [[Malibu, California]].{{cite news|title=Girl hurt by item cast from Kenny G's home|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/jun/30/local/me-kennyg30|accessdate=May 25, 2011|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=June 30, 2007}} He is an avid [[golf]]er and has a [[Handicap (golf)|handicap]] of +0.6. He has participated in the [[AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am]] tournament seven times as of 2007 and teamed with [[Phil Mickelson]] to share the AT&T pro-am title in 2001 with the team of [[Tiger Woods]] and Jerry Chang. In the [[Golf Digest]] rankings of Top 100 in Music, according to golf handicap indexes of major musicians, he was first in 2006 and second in 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.golfdigest.com/golf-tours-news/musicians |title=The Top 100 in Music |accessdate=April 3, 2010 |last=Furlong |first=Lisa |coauthors=Craig Bestrom |date=2008-11 |work=Golf Digest |publisher=Condé Nast Digital }} He is a member at [[Sherwood Country Club]] in [[Thousand Oaks, California]]. Kenny G is an [[aircraft pilot]] and has a [[de Havilland Canada DHC-2 Beaver|De Havilland Beaver]] seaplane that he flies regularly.{{cite news | first=Neil | last=Strauss | title=... And Two if by Seaplane | date=October 31, 2006 | url =http://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/08/garden/and-two-if-by-seaplane.html?pagewanted=1 | work=The New York Times | accessdate =April 3, 2010 }} He was also an early investor in the [[Starbucks]] coffee house chain.{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN2537209120080126 |title=Q&A: Kenny G explores Latin "Rhythm" |accessdate=April 3, 2010 |last=Harding |first=Cortney |date=January 25, 2008 |agency=Reuters |publisher=Thomson Reuters }} ==Discography== {{main|Kenny G discography}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links ==
